title: Tyson Fury hits back at Deontay Wilder over claim he'll pull out of rematch
text:
The Gypsy King is adamant he will not be responsible if the rematch falls through (Picture: Getty)

Tyson Fury has rubbished suggestions his move into WWE could scupper a rematch with Deontay Wilder at the start of next year and says the American is more likely to pull out.

The Gypsy King will take on Braun Strowman in Saudi Arabia on Halloween despite still recovering from a severe cut over his eye sustained in his last fight with Otto Wallin.

Wilder has suggested Fury is already getting his ‘excuses’ in and does not want to rematch him, while the Brit believes the biggest threat to the fight is Wilder’s rematch with Luis Ortiz.

Fury takes on Braun Strowman at WWE Crown Jewell at the end of the month (Picture: Getty)

Asked if he still believes their fight will go ahead as planned in February, Fury told Boxing Social: ‘It’s not me. Wilder’s got to fight Ortiz, so we’ll see how that fight goes and then make a decision on whether it’s going to be in February or not.

‘If he loses, it’s definitely not going to be in February is it? It’s not going to happen at all. He’s going to have a rematch with Ortiz. So then we’ll have to look for a new opponent for February 22. Either or, I’ll be fighting on February 22.

‘Whatever happens in other people’s lives and careers, it’s none of my concern, but my life and career I’ll be boxing February 22 in Las Vegas that’s for sure. Whether the cut is okay or not, I’ll still be fighting February 22 because that’s what I do!’

In a further interview with IFL TV, Fury expanded: ‘What happens if Wilder gets [knocked out]? Everyone is overlooking Ortiz like he’s a bum. Wow! Although the guy is 50 years old he’s still dangerous for four rounds.

‘Don’t go to sleep on Luis Ortiz, because he’s a monster. He’s definitely a bad old man, that’s for sure. And he’s dangerous in four rounds. In four or five rounds he’s as good if not more dangerous than anyone in the world. So don’t go to sleep on him.

Big-hitting heavyweights Wilder and Ortiz will face off for the second time in November (Picture: Getty)

‘If you overlook him, you’ll go to sleep just like AJ did. So don’t concentrate on me, concentrate on what Deontay Wilder is going to do. Leave me wrestling alone. If I get injured, I get injured. But he’s more likely to get injured than me.

‘The thing is, it’s not me that’s going to get pulled out, or because I don’t want to fight in February, it will be because he’s had a tough fight. “Oh I can’t go in February because I’m injured” or he’s been beat or whatever.’

Probed on whether he thinks that would happen, he added: ‘Is it not possible? It’s heavyweight boxing isn’t it? Do bears s*** in the woods?’
